lexUnit.name: fly.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: (of a winged creature or aircraft) move through the air under control.

sentence.text: The bird looked up and flew away .
Imagine the colour of that bird and imagine it gracefully flying .
Out in the open the bird can fly enormous distances , so even if you spotted one , the chances are it would have flown miles away before you could get your camera ready to shoot .
All that appeared was a shot of the sky with the occasional bird flying past .
If the nest is a hanging one , then the bird will fly round and round the first threads , binding more around them to form the walls of the cup .
Looking up to the blue sky , she watched the many birds flying overhead , chattering and screaming as they passed out of sight .
And then she reproached him and turned into a dragon , and flew away round the battlements making a terrible noise and battering the stones .
This is followed by a horizontally scrolling scene featuring a dragon flying over a rocky landscape ( it would look a bit silly if it were cycling over it ) .
As the dragons fly further away they begin to dwindle .
They were sparse , little more than a wide and overgrown hedge , but at least no dragon would be able to fly through them .
Someone pretty old told us moths flew to light .
When he opened it moths flew out and he had to give it a good clean to get rid of the cobwebs and years of dust that had settled inside .
Presumably , this is what moths are doing when they fly into a candle and are burnt to death .
And if the parents are to get all the food they need , it must be in an area where there is a great number of moths and other insects flying at night .
A moth flew past her face , making her jump , and his grasp tightened around her waist .
Flying low across the track was a formation of swans -- five of them at least -- their anxious , elongated necks rigid with effort ; their great wings beating in slow motion .
I decided not to fly at him .
Bernice saw creatures flying in the sky about two kilometres away .
If at any point they lose the scent they fly in zig-zags from side to side until they catch it again , and then fly off upwind again .
Mould let out an almighty scream and flew into the air .
A cuckoo flew low over the reed bed , to be mobbed at once by two reed warblers .
` FLIGHT TO FREEDOM " read the headline of one over a picture of the unusual sight of a golden eagle flying over Regent 's Park .
Imagine you are flying through the air -- raise both arms and legs simultaneously .

It features close-up shots of fox cubs playing in woods near Wilton , bats flying through open windows into laboratories and a mole digging for worms within yards of workmen sinking salt wells at North Tees .
Then it flew to a boulder , blinked its white eyelids , bobbed and curtsied , and whirred upstream .
Sure enough , a couple of rock doves fly out of the crack with a clatter of wings , and we can see a scarcely fledged youngster perched on a ledge in the gloom of the sea-cave .
Pelicans flew about swooping suddenly into the water to dive for fish .
A bumble bee flew frantically up the motorway with his back legs crossed , stopping briefly at each motorway service area as he passed it and muttering to himself :
Now 32 carriers are flying into Tegel Airport , foremost among them Lufthansa , which was founded in Berlin in 1926 .
